statement:
Let $f:{\mathbb{R}}\to {\mathbb{R}}$ be a function which is continuous
on the interval $[a,b]$ and differentiable on $(a,b)$. Then there exists
a number $c: a < c < b$ such that

$$f'(c) = \frac{f(b) - f(a)}{b - a}.$$

The geometrical meaning of this theorem is illustrated in the picture:\

![image](mittelwertsatz.ps)

The dashed line connects the points $(a,f(a))$ and $(b,f(b))$. There is
$c$ between $a$ and $b$ at which the tangent to $f$ has the same slope
as the dashed line.

The mean-value theorem is often used in the integral context: There is a
$c \in [a,b]$ such that

$$(b-a)f(c) = \int_{a}^{b} f(x) dx.$$
